I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  On 30 April 2020, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a loan of $100 million 
from concessional ordinary capital resources (COL) for the COVID-19 Response Emergency 
Assistance Project.1 The loan was signed on 13 May 2020, became effective on 16 May 2020, 
and will close on 31 October 2023. The project will support the government’s efforts under its 
National Preparedness and Response Plan to contain, mitigate, and manage the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19).2 The ongoing project supports procurement of equipment and supplies, 
upgrading of health and testing facilities, and building system and community capacities for 
surveillance, prevention, and response to COVID-19. The Directorate General of Health Services 
(DGH) under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) is the implementing agency of 
the project. As of 30 November 2020, no contract has been awarded, and $10 million has been 
disbursed from the advance account. The project is rated for attention due to procurement delay. 
 
2.  The ongoing project is aligned with the following impact: Accelerated social and economic 
recovery of COVID-19 affected population in Bangladesh (footnote 2). The project will have the 
following outcome: health and well-being of COVID-19 affected persons improved. The outcome 
will be achieved through three outputs: (i) immediate and medium-term equipment needs for 
testing and managing COVID-19 met; (ii) infrastructure and related equipment for supporting and 
sustaining prevention and management of COVID-19 delivered; and (iii) health system and 
community capacities in combatting COVID-19 strengthened.  
 
3.  Under output 1, the project will help meet the government’s immediate and medium-term 
needs to prevent the spread of COVID-19, by supporting emergency procurement and provision 
of the most crucial medical equipment and supplies. These will help treat and protect affected 
people and healthcare workers from infection, and equip selected health facilities with essential 
infection prevention and control supplies. Output 2 will support modification and rehabilitation of 
infrastructure which includes providing screening facilities at air, land, and sea ports of entries; 
equipping medical college hospitals with critical care units and isolation units to reduce  secondary 
infections; and strengthening microbiological diagnostic facilities’ capability to apply real-time and 
advanced diagnostics. Output 3 will support measures to strengthen health system’s response 
capacities and implement short- and medium-term capacity development, such as incentives to 
frontline health workers, operational research on COVID-19, and COVID-19 risk communication 
strategy and plan. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  The COVID-19 outbreak, declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) 
on 11 March 2020, has spread rapidly across the globe, with severe impact on lives and 
economies. In Bangladesh, the first case was reported on 8 March 2020. Cases have risen steeply 
with 464,932 confirmed cases and 6,644 deaths as of 30 November 2020.3 The country is now in 
a fourth stage of infection (community transmission).  
 
 
1  The approved Report and Recommendation of the President of the project is in Appendix 2. 
2  Government of Bangladesh, MOHFW. 2020. National Preparedness and Response Plan for COVID-19 Bangladesh. 
Version 5. 18 March 2020. Dhaka. 
3  Coronavirus COVID-19 Dashboard, 2020. Government of Bangladesh, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

2 
5.  High population density,4 rapid urbanization, a large population of migrant workers, and 
more  than  20%  of  its  urban  population  living  in  slums  without  adequate  sanitation,  made 
Bangladesh vulnerable to infectious disease outbreaks. The pandemic has led to significant 
negative impact on the economy with gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate projected to 
decline to 5.2% in FY2020 from 8.2% in FY2019.5 ADB estimates indicate that job losses could 
be as high as 3.7 million; many informal workers (85.1% of the workforce) 6 lost their livelihoods 
instantly after the nationwide lockdown. With 20.5% of the population under the poverty line, and 
10.5% living in extreme poverty (FY2019),7 Bangladesh is especially vulnerable to economic 
shocks. Any economic shock would push a significant proportion of the near poor under the 
poverty line and deepen the poverty of those already poor, reversing previous gains made in 
poverty reduction. It is, therefore, crucial to support Bangladesh’s efforts to mitigate the impact 
and flatten the curve for COVID-19 as well as strengthen health system’s capacity in the medium- 
to long-term to deal with such health emergencies in the future. 
 
6.  The health sector is in the front line of the battle against health emergencies, both in its 
role as provider of health services to the public and as victims in terms of the high toll the COVID-
19  has  already  taken  on  health  sector  workers.  However,  according  to  WHO’s  scale  of 
International Health Regulations core capacities, Bangladesh has limited capacity to prevent, 
detect, and respond to public health emergencies.8 Overall, the health system is underdeveloped 
and underfunded, with only 9.9 doctors, nurses and midwives9 and 8.8 hospital beds per 10,000 
people.10 Current health expenditure is only 2.3% of gross domestic product, while out-of-pocket 
expenditure accounts for over two-thirds of health spending, making healthcare unaffordable to 
many.11 Business process of procurement of drugs and equipment, and inventory and warehouse 
management is inefficient. Key categories of need include: (i) the capacity of the health sector to 
assess and monitor the COVID-19 pandemic (and other emerging diseases); (ii) the capacity of 
the health sector to handle and cure suspected and probable COVID-19 patients (health facilities, 
medical  and  laboratory  equipment,  and  supplies);  (iii)  the  needs  of  health  personnel  for 
information, protection, and training; (iv) information, education, and communication campaigns 
for health professionals and the public on COVID-19 and other future health emergencies; and (v) 
hygienic disinfection and appropriate sanitary measures to prevent spread of diseases.12 
 
7.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) will provide capacity building and implementation 
support to expedite the implementation of the ongoing project, develop automated medicines and 
equipment procurement and logistics management system, establish effective monitoring and 
evaluation system. The TA will also support medium to long term efforts to build health system 
capacity to respond quickly and flexibly to prevent and contain future emergencies, and provide 
technical support for planning and developing future ADB-assisted investment projects to help

communicable disease prevention and control.13 
 
8.  Given the emergency nature of the project, and the overburdened government resources 
to respond to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, the government needs consulting services to 
support the implementation of the ongoing emergency assistance project to achieve intended 
results in a smooth and timely manner.  As loan proceeds will be used to maximize immediate 
support to procure medical equipment and supplies, and rehabilitate infrastructure for critical care 
units and isolation units, allocation for consulting services needs to be augmented through the 
TA.  In addition, the TA will finance strengthening the health system and community capacities 
(output 3 of ongoing project). The TA will also respond to additional needs identified by the 
government to further strengthen the health system’s capacity to combat future contagion, such 
as  the  installation  of  distributed  automation  system  (DSA),  standardizing  border  screening 
procedures, strengthening medical programs, and developing future investment pipelines for the 
health sector.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Strengthened implementation capacity for COVID-19 response. Technical 
expertise and capacity building support will be provided to executing and implementing agencies 
for the successful implementation of COVID-19 Response Emergency Assistance Project.  The 
TA will fill gaps in loan resources allocated for project implementation support (para. 8). Output 1 
will provide support in the following areas: (i) carrying out procurement of equipment, works, 
goods and consultant packages including stockpiling of emergency medical equipment and drug 
supply,  and  inventory  system; (ii)  coordinating human resources  development  and training 
arrangements; and (iii) strengthening project coordination, procurement, financial management 
and governance, and safeguards systems in the project implementing unit (PIU). 
 
10.  Output 2. Enhanced health system and community capacities to combat future 
contagion. Output 2 will support measures to strengthen the health system’s response capacities 
and its medium- to long-term capacity development. To improve the efficiency of procurement, 
inventory and warehouse management of medical supplies and equipment, Central Medical 
Stores Depot (CMSD) business processes will be re-engineered by assessing its procurement 
system, piloting an innovative IT-based DSA in CMSD, and rolling it out to other districts. To 
improve surveillance, cross-border screening procedures will be standardized, and regional 
sharing of health monitoring and surveillance information will be supported. Human resource 
development in the health sector will be supported by strengthening infection prevention and 
control programs of medical schools. Public awareness on communicable disease prevention and 
control will be heightened through information and education campaigns.  Target beneficiaries of 
the activities will be confirmed during the TA inception mission. The TA will also facilitate the 
strategic planning and development of ADB’s future investment projects to meet long-term needs 
for the health systems towards building resilient systems and addressing future health security 
threats posed by communicable disease outbreaks.  
 
11.  The proposed support for design and installation of DSA system for CMSD will be an 
innovative approach in strengthening the health system of Bangladesh and supporting its COVID-
19 response. The DSA system will be designed to have inter-operability with other health 
information systems in Bangladesh, particularly, the District Health Information Software 2, an 
 
13 The technical assistance first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 29 April 2020.

4 
open source Health Management Information System used by the Ministry of Health for health 
facilities. 
 
12.  Output 3: Established effective monitoring and evaluation system. A well-functioning 
project monitoring and management information system will be established under the project 
implementation unit to monitor progress on procurement, quality of equipment and civil works, 
contract management, implementation, fund flows, accounting, audit, and reporting functions. A 
comprehensive project monitoring dashboard will be developed and operationalized to track 
progress towards achieving project output and outcome indicators in the design and monitoring 
framework.14 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, 
office supplies, secretarial and coordination assistance, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA in consultation with the executing and implementing agencies. 
ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants. ADB will 
recruit  international  and  national  consultants  using  firm  and  individual consultant  selection 
process (paras. 17–18).

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.15  TA implementation 
will be carried out through a mix of firm and international/national individual consultants (69 
person-months). A consulting firm—IT consultant—will be recruited through open competitive 
bidding procedures, local advertisement, and/or limited competitive bidding using quality- and 
cost-based selection method, simplified technical proposal, or biodata technical proposal. Other 
selection methods such as consultants’ qualification-based selection is also envisaged. Individual 
consultants will be recruited for other positions as needed, following individual selection method, 
international or local advertisement, based on project requirements. Education campaigns on 
communicable disease prevention and control may be provided using local nongovernment 
organizations. The option for direct contract or memorandum of understanding with the UN 
agencies will also be explored, as appropriate.  
 
17.  DSA Specialist/project management consultant will act as an advisor to the executing and 
implementing agencies to support preparation of DSA design and specification, and monitoring 
and supervision of DSA installation. IT consultant will procure, install, and configure the IT and 
network infrastructure for DSA. The IT consultant will roll out the pilot DSA to other districts, 
support the maintenance of the pilot DSA for one year, and train the CMSD for DSA operation 
and maintenance. DSA specialist under PMC will be involved as an observer in the procurement 
of IT consultant and hardware procurement to ensure compatibility with technical requirements. 
 
E.  Governance  
 
18.  Governance with respect to procurement, recruitment, and financial management will be 
as stated in the report and recommendation of the President (footnote 1).  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
Bangladesh for the Supporting COVID-19 Response Emergency Assistance Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
